meanings.definition: Subject to sudden or unpredictable changes in mood or mind.
meanings.sent1: Her mercurial nature made it hard to predict how she would react to any situation.
meanings.sent2: The weather in spring can be quite mercurial, changing from sunny to rainy in a matter of minutes.
meanings.sent3: His mercurial behavior at the party kept everyone on their toes, never knowing what he would do next.
meanings.sent4: The stock market can be as mercurial as a lightning strike, shifting dramatically in a short period of time.
meanings.sent5: The mercurial artist's mood swings were as unpredictable as the changing colors of a chameleon.

meanings.definition: Relating to or characteristic of the god Mercury.
meanings.sent1: The ancient statue depicted Mercury in a mercurial pose, ready to deliver messages swiftly.
meanings.sent2: The messenger's mercurial speed allowed him to travel great distances in a short time.
meanings.sent3: The mercurial messenger always arrived just in time, as if he had a magical sense of timing.
meanings.sent4: Her dance was as mercurial as the movements of Mercury himself, graceful and swift.
meanings.sent5: The mercurial wings of the messenger god shimmered in the sunlight, reflecting his divine speed.

meanings.definition: Containing or relating to the element mercury.
meanings.sent1: The old thermometer contained mercurial liquid that expanded and contracted with temperature changes.
meanings.sent2: The scientist studied the mercurial properties of the element in the lab.
meanings.sent3: The mercurial substance was carefully handled due to its toxic nature.
meanings.sent4: The mercurial metal flowed like a river when heated, showing its unique properties.
meanings.sent5: The mercurial vapor rose from the spilled element, shimmering in the dim light of the room.
